Directory picker widget for fzf

Tillman Jex, November 06, 2023
Tagged: dotfiles
License: MIT

fzf is of course one of the best tools around.

Out of the box it offers:

  • file and directory search
  • history search
  • “auto cd” (search for a directory and cd into it on selection)

I would say 80% of the time I use fzf to pick files, and therefore have my $FZF_DEFAULT_COMMAND set to only find files.

export FZF_DEFAULT_COMMAND='fd -H -tf'

This then means that I can’t use the CTRL-T keybinding to find directories.

I dug into the zsh functions that come with fzf to replicate the same file picking behaviour, but for directories. It get’s exported as a widget, which you can then use to bind to a keybind of your choice.

In your .zshrc:

# use fzf to search for dirs and paste them inplace, in the current prompt
fzf_dir() {
    cmd=$(fd . --type d | fzf --preview 'tree -C {} | head -200')
    LBUFFER="${LBUFFER}${(q)cmd}"
    local ret=$?
    zle reset-prompt
    return $ret
}

# export the function as a widget
zle -N fzf_dir

# assign the widget to a keybind
bindkey '^d' fzf_dir # set in ./functions

Magic

The magic is happening in LBUFFER="${LBUFFER}${(q)cmd}"

The (q) in ${(q)cmd}, quotes the resulting expanded variable (cmd). In other words, wraps it in quotation marks. This allows file paths with spaces to be interpreted correctly by the shell.

LBUFFER is the contents to the left of the cursor. By setting itself to itself, appended with the expansion of ${(q)cmd}, we are left with the prompt as we had it before, appended by the chosen directory from fzf.
